blocks.text: A TRIP TO MICHIGAN, June 24 to July 1, 1950. Gordon, accompanied by Kitty and the children, drives to Detroit to attend a conference of the International Association of Accident and Health Underwriters aboard the lake steamer "Greater Detroit", which cruises for four days on Lake Huron. From Detroit, while Gordon is attending the conference, Kitty drives the children to her brother-in-law's farm at Shelby, Michigan.

Saturday, June 24, 1950 – Left Lancaster at 8:00 A. M; to Harrisburg; to Sunbury; to Williamsport; to Wellsboro; view "Grand Canyon of Pennsylvania"; north into New York state; night at Fillmore. (293 miles)
At Clark's Ferry, north off of Harrisburg, a detour forces us back across the Susquehanna, so we follow the east bank of the River to Sunbury.
Left - Cindy, Kitty, Nancy, Louise and Kathy.

blocks.text: Trip to Michigan
Ten miles from Wellsboro we view the "Grand Canyon of Pennsylvania" from Leonard Harrison State Park.

North into New York state, we find it difficult to secure accommodations for the night, but finally secure a large room at this hotel in the small town of Fillmore. The town is celebrating its centennial and most of the men have allowed their beards to grow and both men and women are attired in the dress of a century ago.

blocks.text: Breakfast in London. Here, due to the favorable currency exchange rate, we receive a 50¢ bonus on a $5 bill.
We spend the night in this cabin near Ingersoll, in the heart of Ontario's tobacco country.
Across the Ambassador Bridge between Windsor, Ontario and Detroit, Michigan.
Down-town Detroit.
Here, in Detroit, at noon, Gordon goes aboard the "Greater Detroit", and Kitty with the children drives westward across Michigan to Shelby, close to the shore of Lake Michigan.

blocks.text: Trip to Michigan

Every one is impressed with the volume of shipping on the Lake. It is like a main highway for freighters. There is hardly a time when at least one freigher is not in sight. We are told one of these freight- ers will haul as much as three long freight trains.

blocks.text: Trip to Michigan

Into Georgian Bay, our first stop on Tuesday evening is at Midland, Ontario, a town of more than 7,000 people, a shopping and industrial center for the 30,000 Island vacation area, a region often referred to as "Huronia" for the once powerful Indian empire of the Hurons.

On Wednesday evening we approach the giant locks at Sault St. Marie ("The Soo") through which more traffic passes than passes through the Panama and Suez Canals combined. The locks raise and lower freighters 21 feet between Lake Superior and Lake Huron.

blocks.text:
OLD FORT MACKINAC
Old Fort Mackinac, once the Gilchetter of America, was built by the British under the direction of Captain Patrick Sinclair in (1708 - 1796). It served as a fort for over one hundred years. The French and Indians were carried over the ice from Michilimackinac One of its earliest forts which was used to protect against attack by an American revolutionary army.
Old Fort Mackinac, once known as St. Joseph's Island or Sable Island, became in 1827 a refuge for escaped slaves on their way northward toward freedom under the terms of the treaty signed at Detroit during the Revolutionary War.
On July 4th, 1836, the island was taken by surprise and forced to surrender to the British. On August 4-9, 1854 The United States made an unsuccessful attempt to retake the fort suffering heavy casualties
At the close of the war of 1812, the fort passed into the Americans through the treaty of Ghent.
Old Fort Mackinac was restored and opened as a museum in (1906), when it was turned over to the State of Michigan by the Federal Government. Old Fort Mackinac and the major part of Mackinac Island are now included in the Michigam island State Park, administered by the Michigan Island State Park Commission
. Trip to Michigan .
The sign recounts the history of Old Fort Mackinac.
Old Fort Mackinac with the statue of Father Marquette who first visited the spot in 1671.

Gordon climbs the path to Old Fort Mackinac for its superb view of the town and the harbor. Behind the Fort wooded carriage roads lead to all parts of the Island, which is less than three miles long by about one half mile wide.

Gordon climbs the path to Old Fort Mackinac for its superb view of the town and the harbor. Behind the Fort wooded carriage roads lead to all parts of the Island, which is less than three miles long by about one half mile wide.

The famous Esther Williams swimming pool at Grand Hotel.

Leaving Mackinac Island Thursday in mid-afternoon, the "Greater Detroit" makes an overnight trip the length of Lake Huron to dock at Detroit the next morning. Our total trip aboard the boat has been about 1,200,miles.
As the "Greater Detroit" swings in the Detroit River to dock, Gordon takes this fine picture of Detroit's skyline.
Friday, at noon, Gordon is met by Kitty and the children who have driven from Shelby to Detroit during the morning.

blocks.text: Trip to Michigan
The Buffalo skyline
We head directly south from Buffalo, visit briefly the Buckwalters at Bradford through the mountains of Pennsylvania to Johnstown.

At Johnstown, we leave Nancy at the Demis where she will be a guest of Betty Demi while Gordon and Kitty are in South Carolina. With the other three chil-dren, we drive to Lancaster over the Pennsylvania Turnpike arriving home at midnight. Cindy, Kathy and Louise are deposited with their grandparents.
End - trip to Michigan.

blocks.text:
A TRIP TO GREENVILLE, SOUTH CAROLINA to attend the National Convention of American Business Clubs, July 2 to July 11, 1950. Gordon and Kitty, Al and Pauline Spinner, Claude and Betty Smith. Trip made in Gordon's and Claude's cars.
Sunday, July 2, 1950 – Lancaster to York: to Hanover; to Fredericksburg

Sunday, July 2, 1950 – Lancaster to York; to Hanover; to Frederick, Md; to Leesburg, Va; to Warrenton; to Culpeper; to Charlottesville (visit Monticello); to Lynchburg; night at outskirts of Roanoke. (300 miles)

With three hours sleep, after the trip from Michigan, Gordon and Kitty are joined by the Spinners and the Smiths and leave Lancaster at 6:30 A. M. Breakfast in Hanover at The Dutch Treat on York Street.

South of Culpeperer, in the rolling foothills of the Blue Ridge as we near Charlottesvilleville, we stop along the roadside in early afternoon to make steaks over a charcoal fire. Left – Claude, Gordon, Al1, Kitty and Pauline. Betty, of course, is the photographer.
Claude appears to have lost his head in the charcoal stove as he encourages the fire with a big blow.

blocks.text: Trip to South Carolina

A few miles outside Charlotteville is Monticello, home of Thomas Jefferson, which he built on the top of a mountain commanding a magnificent view of the valley below. The home is architecturally unique and contains many "gadgets" to delight the visitors. Maintenance today is by a non-profit foundation. Admission to grounds and building is 90¢ per person.
"All my wishes end where I hope my days will end, at Monticello". - Jefferson.

Thomas Jefferson and Martha Washington were married November 4th, 1772 in Charles City County Virginia. Thomas was born on June 13, 1745 at Monticello a distance of more than one hundred miles from their home near Charlottesville. As they approached Monticello it began to snow heavily enough for the ground to be covered with inches of snow. The family reached Richmond before noon and were forced to spend the night in an old brick house on their way up the mountain side through darkness, because of the inclement weather that had brought them there.
Because of the inclemency they stayed until morning when it was safe for them to proceed on their journey home. They returned with a horse and buggy instead of walking as far as possible at night! Not wishing to disturb Thomas Jefferson stalled the horses in front of his lodge kindled a fire, opened the window shutters and spent the night there. The light from this building has been known as "Honeymoon Lodge."
Kitty and Pauline read a sign affixed on their return to Monticello.
The grave of Thomas Jefferson, a short distance from Monticello. Jefferson died at Monticello on July 4, 1826, the fiftieth anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of American Independence.

blocks.text: . Trip to South Carolina .
A southern fried chicken dinner at Lynchburg, a city of many levels on the bluffs of the James River.
Our first night spent here on the outskirts of Roanoke after a drive of 53 miles from Lynchburg. Mountains surround us.
Monday, July 3, 1950 – Over Blue Ridge Parkway to point near Mt. Mitchell in North Carolina; night near Asheville, where we attend a pre-Convention party by Asheville Chapter. (380 miles)

On the Blue Ridge Parkway we come upon this mountain lad who is exploiting the tourist bonanza to the full extent of his wits...a request for money, or he will sell his mon-grel dog for $5 to help a "sick" relative. Although only twelve years old, he chews tobacco and dips snuff, a pinch of the latter Claude and Gordon politely accept to their regret.
Here the Parkway is a broad plateau. Note the snake fence. Picture taken from tower shown at left.

HOMESTEAD
IN THE HOLLOW BELOW IS THE LOG DWELLING IN WHICH A HARDY PIONEER, HARRISON CALDWELL, AND WIFE JOSIE RAISED A FAMILY OF THEIR CLEARING. STILL TRACEABLE POWERED CORN POTATOES AND OTHER NEEDS AND THE FOREST WILD GAME FOR THE TABLE. THE WAY TO ABSHER, THE NEAREST HAMLET: IS HALF BY FOOT TRAIL. MALE BY THE "ABSHOR ROAD."
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR
NATIONAL PARK SERVICE

blocks.text: Tuesday, July 4, 1950 – We have a late breakfast in Asheville, and then drive a leisurely 65 miles due south to Greenville, S. C., where we arrive in mid-afternoon. The country between Asheville and Greenville is rolling, but we are surprised there are no high mountains.
Close to the South Carolina line is Lake Summit, where we stop for refreshments.
WELCOME ABC's NATIONAL CONVENTION • AMERICAN BUSINESS CLUBS JULY 4.5.6.7
The Hotel Poinsett, in Greenvilleville, ist the headquarters for the Convention. Lower right - the delegates relax at a picnic in a nearby state park.

blocks.text: . Trip to South Carolina .

Saturday, July 8, 1950 – The return trip from Greenville. Al, Pauline, Claude and Betty leave early in the morning for Lancaster by the most direct route. Gordon and Kitty leave Greenville about 1:00 P. M.; to Highlands, N. C; to Franklin; to a point near Cherokee for the night. (160 miles)
As we approach Cashiers, N. C., we cross the Toxaway River, with the mountains in the background."
An attractive little wayside restaurant where we are charged $1 for two cups of coffee and two small sandwiches. (Live and learn!)
A region of stark, sheer granite mountains as we approach Highlands from Cashiers.

blocks.text: Highlands, N. C., said to be the highest incorporated town in the East, is a resort center in an area which contains more varieties of plants than any similar area in America. The region was early visited by white men, for De Soto came this way in 1540 in search for gold.
Between Highlands and Franklin, N. C., are three interesting waterfalls, which we had seen in 1948 on our trip to Savannahnhall.
Just outside Highlands is Bridal Veil Falls where a small stream pours over the highway.

blocks.text: Trip to South Carolina
A unique roadside restaurant, with a giant water-wheel, in the mountains near Dillsboro, N. C. Gordon and Kitty have dinner here...

Cherokee once again, in the Indian Reservation, which we reach as darkness is falling. We are told we are lucky to find accommodations within fifty miles, so great is the influx of tourists. We finally secure a room for the night at a private home six miles from the town.

blocks.text: Sunday, July 9, 1950 – Across the Great Smokies to Gatlinburg, Tenn; west along the base of the mountains to Maryville; to Knoxville; visit Norris Dam; through Cumberland Gap to Middleboro, Ky; through coal regions of southeastern Kentucky almost to Pikeville for the night. (323 miles)
. Trip to South Carolina .
An early morning breakfast as we return to Cherokee to cross the Great Smokies.
Knoxville
Yellow Creek Mountain National Park.
To Murphy's Rock Stecoah To Murphy's

The road over the Great Smokies from Cherokee to Gatlinburg provides the finest mountain views in eastern America. The Great Smoky Mountains National Park em-braces some 440,000 acres, 687 square miles, of the last remnant of primeval wilderness in the East, much of it almost entirely unknown fifty years ago.

blocks.text: We follow the Oconalufky River north from Cherokee and soon enter the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

From Newfound Gap, elevation 5,048 ft., on the boundary between North Carolina and Tennessee, our road from Cherokee can be seen winding up along the side of the moun-tains. The rise is 3,000 feet in less than twenty miles.

blocks.text: . Trip to South Carolina .
The road cuts a hugh slice out of the side of the mountain. The roadcuts acuts a huggh sliice ouf oof tthe side of thte mounntainstain..
A tunnel eases the rapidity of the descent into Tennessee.
Just before Gatlinburg, we turn left and follow Fighting Creek for miles along the foot of the mountains. The road is narrow with many curves.
The "Chimneys", a famous landmark, rise over the road.
By noon we are in Knoxville, largest city of the Upper Tennessee Valley, seat of the University of Tennessee.

blocks.text: Norris Dam, 21 miles northwest of Knoxville, was the first dam built in the great TVA system. Work was begun in 1933 and completed in 1936 at a cost of $36,000,000. Norris Dam is 1,860 feet long, 208 feet thick at the base, and 265 feet high.
WELCOME TO KENTUCKY VISIT OUR HISTORIC SHRINES ROADS ARE PATROLLED FOR YOUR SAFETY DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS

We drive along the foothills of the Cumberland hills of the Cumberland Mountains,
pass through the Cumberland Gap to enter Kentucky.

blocks.text: Cumberland Gap is the only natural divide through the Cumberland Mountains. It was a part of Warrior's Path used before the white man came. In 1775 Daniel Boone opened a route through the Gap through which settlers migrated to open the West.
The Pinnacles which overlook Cumberland Gap, 2,465 feet in height, command a magnificent view of points in six states.

blocks.text: . Trip to South Carolina .

Through the grim, drab soft coal region of south-ern Kentucky, including Harlan County, scene of many a bloody struggle between the miners and the coal companies. We finally have dinner at Pine Mountain Hotel, after driving 75 miles without finding a restaurant suitable for eating. Night near Pikeville at tourist cabins.
Monday, July 10, 1950 – Through Pikeville, Ky; to Williamson, W. Va.; to Charles-ton; to Buchannon; to Morgantown; to Uniontown, Pa for night. (394 miles)
More drab towns and squalid living as the pass through in the soft coal region near Williamson, W. Va.

The capitol of West Virginia at Charleston, where we have had lunch with C. O. Snyder, state manager, at the Daniel Boone Hotel. We leave Char-leston at 4:00 P. M. and make a very fast drive to Buchannon at dusk.
This picture of the capitol building suffers from lack of perspective; but Gordon to get further away would have stepped in the river.

Monday, July 10, 1950 – Through Pikeville, Ky; to Williamson, W. Va.; to Charles-ton; to Buchannon; to Morgantown; to Uniontown, Pa for night. (394 miles)

More drab towns and squalid living as the pass through in the soft coal region near Williamson, W. Va.

The capitol of West Virginia at Charleston, where we have had lunch with C. O. Snyder, state manager, at the Daniel Boone Hotel. We leave Char-leston at 4:00 P. M. and make a very fast drive to Buchannon at dusk.

This picture of the capitol building suffers from lack of perspective; but Gordon to get further away would have stepped in the river.

blocks.text: A TRIP TO VIRGINIA, September 1 – 3, 1950, visiting Williamsburg, Yorktown, Jamestown, Richmond, Charlottesville; return via Skyline Drive. Gordon and Kitty; Bill and Ve Huber.

St. Anne's Episcopal Church, erected in 1768, just a few miles south of Middletown, Del., was the first church building for the congregation that became St. Anne's Episcopal Parish (now known as St. Anne's Episcopal Church) and is located on East Main Street near the intersection with North Broad Street in Delaware City, Delaware.
The State House in Dover, Del., built more than 150 yrs. ago, is one of the oldest in the country still in use.
ACCOMACK C

On the DuPont Highway, we leave Maryland and enter Virginia. The land is very flat. This long peninsula running south from Wilmington to Cape Charles is known as the Delmarva Peninsula, combining the names of three states.

A side trip to Chincoteague Island, Va., ten miles east of the main north-south highway. This island is famous throughout the region for its oysters and seafoodood. Also found here are the wild, Chincoteague ponyries.

By ferry across the broad mouth of Chesapeake Bay, from Kiptopeke to Little Creek. The fare (including tax) for four and the car is $5.39.

Traffic is heavy. We wait forty-five minutes in the hot sun to board a ferry.
We waited forty-five, five-minute minutes
in the hont sunk to boand to booboard a da fererry.
In the hont sunk to boand to booboard a da fererry

The passage requires 1½ hrs. The Bay is so wide here we almost get out of sight of land.
The ppassageagge requireisss 1⅓ hrrs. THe Baeay is sso widde here we almosst geettt out oof sigghhhtt off laand.
We pass two other ferries making their return trip from Little Creek.

blocks.text: Trip to Virginia

Saturday, September 2, 1950 – Breakfast in Virginia Beach; west in a circle around Norfolk; to Portsmouth; across James River bridge; to Yorktown; to Williamsburg; lunch in Williamsburg; o Jamestown; to Richmond (supper); to Charlottesville for night.
Tidewater Water Virginia...along the James River.
Entrance to the 4½ miles long James River bridge. Far in the distance is the high section which permits ships to pass under it. Toll is $1.40 for this bridge and two smaller ones.
A typical road...straight, flat, through many forest areas.

blocks.text: Trip to Virginia

After crossing the James River bridge, we drive
18 miles to Yorktown where Lord Cornwallis in
1781 surrendered to the combined American and
French forces, thus ending the Revolutionary War.
This is an historic peninsula between the James
and York Rivers, containing also Williamsburg

Victory monument at Yorktown
is 95 ft. high, was damaged by lightning in 1942.
French gums at Yorktown.
We inspect the Grand French Battery whose fire contributed greatly to the final surrender.

blocks.text: Trip to Virginia
From Yorktown it is only 12 miles along the beautiful Colonial Parkway to Williamsburg, the restored ancient and historic capital of Virginia.

Williamsburg surpasses all expectations both in the number and the excellence of the restorations. Here it is easy to turn back the pages of time and imagine yourself on the streets of a colonial town.
RALEIGH TAVERN
The day is terrifically hot and we perspire freely without any undue exertion.

The Capitol was the meeting place of the Virginia Assembly and General Court.

blocks.text: Trip to Virginia
Jamestown, located on Jamestown Island, called the first permanent English settlement in America, was founded in 1607. It is only 7 miles from Williamsburg. Today only ruins remain.

From Jamestown, we head northwest along the north shore of the James River, through a deeply forested region of hugh estates fronting on the James Riv- er, to Richmond 55 miles away. Richmond has been the capital of Virginia since 1779 when the seat of government was moved there from Williamsburg.
The Capitol of Virginia is perched on one of Richmond's seven hills, overlooking the James River.

blocks.text: Trip to Virginia
Supper at this barbecue stand just outside Richmond. That black cloud caught up with us before we reached Charlottesvilleville.

On a new road, laid almost straight as an arrow, we travel 72 miles from Richmond to Charlottesville, gradually rising into rolling hills country. A heavy rain storm, which made visibility difficult, caught up with us as we neared Charlottesville.
MONTICELLO HOME and BURIAL PLACE of THOMAS JEFFERSON
After nightfall we secure accommodations at these cottages north of Charlo lottville.
Two months (to the day) since the trip to South Carolina we again visit Monticello.

blocks.text: . Trip to Virginia .

Monticello, famous home of Thomas Jefferson, erected on a hilltop affords a magnificent view. Work was begun in 1770, and in 1772, in the middle of a snow storm, Jefferson and his bride arrived at the partly completed house.

The Rotunda of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville,
erected in 1826, restored in 1898 by Stanford White, is Jeff-
ersons version of the Pantheon. In front of the building is
the Liberty.Bell Statue of Jefferson, who founded the Univ-
ersity and remained its dominating force until his death.
